title.rendered: Twelve (12) Documents for International student Traveling to Canada

content.rendered:
Many factors drive students’ urge to travel Internationally to study. Such factors may include high-quality education, diverse and accepting culture, and access to beautiful natural areas, to mention but a few.

Certain requirements authenticate your readiness to travel and be accepted into Canada. This article will give you 12 important documents that will grant you access to Canada as an international student.

1. International Passport

An international passport is an essential document for traveling internationally. Without an international passport, one cannot travel abroad.

Note: If your passport is yet to expire in six (6) months, you will also be limited to travel abroad.

Other documents that can be considered include

  • Valid Driver’s License
  • Birth Certificate

While in Canada, you are responsible for ensuring your passport is up-to-date. Yes! you need to extend or renew your passport while in Canada,

2. A letter of Acceptance

A letter of acceptance, also called an Offer Letter or an Acceptance Letter, must be provided to receive your approval to obtain a study permit. If you have been accepted into a designated Canadian post-secondary institution, you will have received a letter of acceptance.

Some letters of acceptance are conditional on following some country’s regulations. A common condition is completing Training in any English as a Second Language (ESL) or French as a Second Language (FSL)

3. A Financial Plan

Proof of Financial Support contains such information as evidence that you can fund yourself and your education. To obtain a study permit, this is required as evidence of funds, including both your Tuition Costs and additional Living Costs properly.

Canada requires all international students to provide minimum funds of $10,000 CAD per year, or $833 CAD per month, with additional financial requirements if you bring family members. In the province of Quebec, you must have $11,000 CAD per year.

Ways to Provide Proof of Financial Support

You can provide proof of financial support in the following ways

  • A bank Draft that can be converted to Canadian dollars
  • A Guaranteed Investment Certificate (GIC) from a participating Canadian financial institution
  • A letter from the household giving you support
  • Proof of a Canadian bank account with your name if you’ve transferred money to Canada
  • Proof of a student or education loan from a bank
  • Proof of funding paid from within Canada if you have a scholarship or are in a Canadian-funded educational program
  • Proof showing that you’ve paid tuition and housing fees
  • Your bank statements for the past four months

4. A study permit

The difference between a Study Permit and a Student Visa is that a study permit allows you to stay in Canada and study, while a Student Visa allows you to enter Canada. A study permit costs $150 CAD.

Documents Required to Obtain Study Permit in any Country including Canada

  • Proof of acceptance
  • Proof of identity (passport)
  • Proof of financial support
  • A letter of explanation or statement of purpose
  • A certificat d’acceptation du Quebec (CAQ):
  • A custodian declaration (minors only
  • Other documents: All documents indicated and specified on the document checklist by your local visa office must be included in the application.

5. Find Accommodation

You need secure accommodation set up when arriving at the University. Ways to reach out for accommodation could be finding other students from different social media groups or using any portal providing such services. You should start planning your accommodation as soon as you have been accepted to university.

Main Types of Accommodation For International Students:

  • On-campus student residences:
  • Off-campus housing in an apartment or house:
  • Homestay.
  • Short-term furnished rentals:

6. Student Health Insurance

All International Students and scholars in Canada need to have introductory and extended health insurance. Not all businesses provide intimately funded health insurance to transnational scholars. Depending on your position, you may qualify for parochial health content or need to get university-handed or private health insurance.

Provincial health insurance covers health basics but doesn’t cover dental care, vision care, and more specific health enterprises, depending on your fiefdom. Transnational scholars with valid study permits can be admitted on a parochial health insurance card in some businesses.

Private health insurance has further individualized plans to cover your specific extended requirements. Some universities have pupil health insurance programs to cover extended health care. Speak to your academy’s transnational scholars’ department to find your stylish health insurance options.

7. A Copy of Your Medical Records And Ongoing Prescriptions

Before leaving home, you should ask your doctor’s office for a duplicate of your medical and immunization records. Any ongoing health enterprises or prescriptions should be noted so that you can continue treating them when you start studying in Canada. Numerous Canadian universities have a clinic on-site or nearby if you need medical attention at school.

8. A Canadian bank account

You also need a bank that understands your needs as a New Customer and a student.

Find a List of Banks in Canada here and open an account

To open a student bank account with RBC, you will require the following documents:

  • Your passport
  • Student permit (IMM 1442) or Temporary Resident Visa (TRV)
  • Proof of enrollment (optional but recommended; can be acquired from your university)
  • Social Insurance Number (SIN) or proof of residence (optional but recommended)

9. A List of Emergency Contacts

Your university may ask you to list exigency connections and their phone figures in case of an accident or exigency. Pick one or two family members or close musketeers in your home country to list as your exigency contact. You may also wish to include an exigency contact in Canada if you have close family or musketeers.

10. A cell phone plan

11. A laptop computer or tablet

12. Winter Gear:

Layering clothes is key in cold conditions. Consider picking up a few of these items when it starts to get chilly in October or Mayember:

  • Gloves, hat, and scarf
  • Long pants
  • Thin long-sleeve shirts to layer under sweaters
  • Warm sleepwear
  • Waterproof boots
  • Thick socks
  • A quality winter jacket
  • A rain jacket and umbrella are needed in rainier cities (e.g., Vancouver, Halifax, etc.)
